issue.title: [ENH] sktime-pywatts integration - umbrella issue

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
The `sktime` and `pywatts` packages have decided to explore integration, especially of the `keras`-like pipeline architecture that `pywatts` has.

This issue is an umbrella issue for that integration and collects work items.

- [ ] high-priority design item: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2654
- [ ] high-priority design item: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2655
- [ ] further design items
- [ ] design exploration:
   - [ ] current `sktime`/`pywatts` closest interface points for transformers: #2918
   - [ ] `sktime` simple `GraphPipeline` using `__call__` dunder: #2919
   - [ ] subsetting transform and `[]` dunder: #2907
- [ ] implementation (sub-items tbd)

Minutes of meetings and design sketches can be found here (file name YYYYMMDD-pywatts.md):
https://github.com/sktime/community-org/tree/main/meetups/previous_meetings

Project board:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/projects/30

body:
key decision is: `xarray` hard dependency vs `xarray` soft dependency. (an option is moving away from it, but I think that's a bad option, because `pywatts` relies on `xarray` and some users may like it)

pro soft dependency, con hard dependency:
* minimizing dependencies for `sktime`
* `xarray` is not commonly used
* we will probably have more types supported in the future, e.g., darts and gluonts specific time series formats. These will also have to rely on soft dependency handling, because we will not want to make darts/gluonts hard dependencies
* `sklearn` does not rely on `xarray` as a hard dependency

con soft dependency, pro hard dependency:
* less logic needed to handle checks and imports in said checks (but we need to deal with this anyway for gluonts, so this is not necessarily the decision opportunity cost)
* `pywatts` relies on `xarray` as a hard dependency

added information: `pywatts` uses mainly 1D and 2D (uni, multivariate series), and occasionally 3D `xarray` for panels arising from bootstrap operations such as window bootstrap, similar to @ltsaprounis' classes in `bootstrap` that output `Panel` when given a `Series`

issue.title: [ENH] How to deal with mtypes that have soft dependencies?

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
The following question is emerging from two different workstreams, deep learning and pywatts.

How do we deal with mtypes that rely on soft dependencies? In the `datatypes` module.

Example 1: `xarray` (series, panel, and hierarchical), as used in `pywatts`. FYI @benheid, @kalebphipps, @smeisen
Related: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2655

Example 2: `ListDataset` (panel data), as used in `gluonts`. FYI @TNTran92, @AurumnPegasus, @ltsaprounis.
Related: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2893

The main problem is that adding examples naively, as of now, would attach the soft dependency imports to large parts of the `datatypes` module.

Some ways out:

* encapsulation as fixtures, similar to `pytest`, or directly via `pytest`, with imports inside the fixture. Plus, calling fixtures only when soft dependencies are installed.
* relying on checks that does not import, or only imports late. E.g., instead of `isinstance(obj, ListDataset)`, use `type(obj).__name__ == "ListDataset"` etc.

Any good ideas?

issue.title: [BUG] Update Predict Only Works with the mtypes pd.Series and pd.DataFrames

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
UpdatePredict only works with the mtypes pd.Series and pd.DataFrames even if the documentation states that also numpy is supported However, if numpy is selected an error is raised. Even if all are from the  scitype Series.

**To Reproduce**

```python
from sktime.forecasting.ets import AutoETS
import numpy as np
ets = AutoETS()
ets.fit(np.random.random(100))
ets.update_predict(np.random.random(10))```
```


**Expected behavior**
I would expect that update_predict works with every mtype that implements the series scitype. If this is not possible, I would suggest that the documentation of update_predict in forecasting._base is updated. 


**Additional context**
I suppose that it would work if in line 2210 of forecasting._base the instance is checked against a list of all scitypes instead of only checked against the pd.Series and pd.DataFrames.

If it should also work with np.arrays, I can take a look if it is possible to check the against all mtypes.

This issue affects also the issues which proposes to add new mtypes. E.g., #2655


**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.18362-SP0
Python dependencies:
          pip: 22.0.3
   setuptools: 60.8.2
      sklearn: 1.0.2
       sktime: 0.13.1
  statsmodels: 0.13.2
        numpy: 1.21.6
        scipy: 1.7.3
       pandas: 1.4.1
   matplotlib: 3.5.1
       joblib: 1.1.0
        numba: 0.55.1
     pmdarima: 1.8.5
      tsfresh: None
</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

body: reopening since `Panel` and `Hierarchical` support is still pending.
